verses.text: The word that came to Jeremiah from the LORD after Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard had released him from Ramah, when he had taken him bound in chains among all the captives of Jerusalem and Judah who were carried away to Babylon.
verses.comment: This introduction sets the stage for Jeremiah's release after the fall of Jerusalem, connecting events back to the previous chapters. The focus on Jeremiah's prophetic role underlines his perseverance in faith, which early Christian interpreters saw as a prefiguring of Christ's suffering for his people.

verses.text: And the captain of the guard took Jeremiah and said to him, "The LORD your God pronounced this disaster upon this place.
verses.comment: Remarkably, a Babylonian official acknowledges the LORD's sovereignty and Jeremiah's prophetic authority. The understanding of God's universal rule is echoed in the New Testament prophecies, showing God working through history and nations.

verses.text: And the LORD has brought it about, and has done just as He said. Because you sinned against the LORD and did not listen to His voice, this thing has come upon you.
verses.comment: This verse affirms both divine judgment and the necessity of obedience, themes central from Deuteronomy through the prophets. The recognition of fulfilled prophecy by a Gentile reminds us that God's plan encompasses all nations (see Luke 2:32).

verses.text: Now, see, I am freeing you today from the chains on your hands. If it seems good to you to come with me to Babylon, come, and I will look after you. But if it seems wrong for you to come with me to Babylon, stay here. See, all the land is before you; go wherever you think it is good and right to go.
verses.comment: The language recalls Abraham's freedom to choose his land (Genesis 13:9), prefiguring the Christian teaching that true freedom comes when we entrust ourselves to God's providence and direction.

verses.text: But before Jeremiah turned to go, Nebuzaradan added, "Go back to Gedaliah the son of Ahikam, son of Shaphan, whom the king of Babylon has appointed over the cities of Judah, and dwell with him among the people, or go wherever it seems right for you to go." So the captain of the guard gave him provisions and a gift and let him go.
verses.comment: Gedaliah’s appointment shows the continuity of leadership in the land and care for the remnant. The giving of provisions mirrors God's ongoing care for His faithful, paralleling the provision for servants of God seen throughout the Bible.

verses.text: Then Jeremiah went to Gedaliah the son of Ahikam at Mizpah, and lived with him among the people who were left in the land.
verses.comment: Jeremiah’s choice to remain with the remnant highlights the importance of staying with God’s people, even in hard times—a principle echoed in the unity and visible community that Christ would later emphasize.

verses.text: Now when all the commanders of the forces in the open country, they and their men, heard that the king of Babylon had appointed Gedaliah the son of Ahikam governor in the land, and had committed to him men, women, and children, those of the poor of the land who had not been taken into exile to Babylon,
verses.comment: Even amid judgment, the presence of a faithful remnant and the poor cared for shows God’s mercy. The care for the poor is a theme integral to the prophets and fulfilled in the teachings of Christ (see Matt. 5:3).

verses.text: they came to Gedaliah at Mizpah—even Ishmael the son of Nethaniah, Johanan and Jonathan the sons of Kareah, Seraiah the son of Tanhumeth, the sons of Ephai the Netophathite, and Jezaniah the son of the Maacathite, they and their men.
verses.comment: Listing these men shows their importance in the unfolding events. The gathering to the appointed governor prefigures the call to faithful unity around legitimate authority.

verses.text: And Gedaliah the son of Ahikam, son of Shaphan, took an oath to them and to their men, saying, "Do not be afraid to serve the Chaldeans. Dwell in the land and serve the king of Babylon, and it shall go well with you."
verses.comment: Gedaliah calls for peaceful cooperation under foreign rule, paralleling Jeremiah's earlier advice. Obedience to lawful authorities is a value carried into the New Testament, connected to God's providence.

verses.text: "As for me, I will dwell at Mizpah to represent you before the Chaldeans who come to us. But as for you, gather wine and summer fruit and oil, and store them in your vessels, and dwell in your cities that you have taken."
verses.comment: Gedaliah acts as a mediator for the people, highlighting the importance of peaceful leadership that cares for both spiritual and temporal needs—a theme developed throughout salvation history.

verses.text: Likewise, when all the Jews who were in Moab and among the Ammonites and in Edom and in all the countries heard that the king of Babylon had left a remnant of Judah, and had set over them Gedaliah the son of Ahikam, son of Shaphan,
verses.comment: Even the exiles in foreign lands look to return to the remnant, reflecting the draw toward the unity of God’s people. The re-gathering hints at restoration motifs used in eschatological and messianic prophecies.

verses.text: then all the Jews returned from all the places to which they had been driven, and came to the land of Judah, to Gedaliah at Mizpah. And they gathered wine and summer fruit in great abundance.
verses.comment: The abundance hints at God’s blessing even after judgment. Restoration involves not only physical return but also spiritual fruitfulness, an image Christ uses for the Kingdom of God (see John 15:5).

verses.text: Now Johanan the son of Kareah and all the commanders of the forces in the open country came to Gedaliah at Mizpah
verses.comment: Local leaders gather at Mizpah, showing the practical importance of legitimate governance and the need for united leadership among God’s people—a principle later emphasized by the apostles.

verses.text: and said to him, "Do you know that Baalis the king of the Ammonites has sent Ishmael the son of Nethaniah to take your life?" But Gedaliah the son of Ahikam did not believe them.
verses.comment: The warning about a plot parallels instances where God’s anointed leaders face betrayal—foreshadowing later betrayals in both Old and New Testaments (cf. Matt. 26:14-16).

verses.text: Then Johanan the son of Kareah spoke privately to Gedaliah at Mizpah, saying, "Let me go and kill Ishmael the son of Nethaniah, and no one will know it. Why should he take your life, so that all the Jews who are gathered to you would be scattered, and the remnant of Judah would perish?"
verses.comment: Johanan’s offer reminds us of Peter’s misguided defense of Jesus in Gethsemane. Human solutions to spiritual problems often lack faith in God’s plan for His people.

verses.text: But Gedaliah the son of Ahikam said to Johanan the son of Kareah, "You shall not do this thing, for you are speaking falsely about Ishmael."
verses.comment: Gedaliah’s refusal to act on suspicion leads to his downfall, yet his innocence is reminiscent of the suffering servant motif—choosing trust over violence. This prefigures the attitude shown by Jesus before his Passion.
